content:
âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: Interesting puzzle: Clear statements and many tests cases.

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's an interesting problem and there's a good number of test cases.

I think it would be good to clarify in the statement that the codon_table maps triplet to an amino acid.

This part confused me and I had to look at the proposed solution to figure out what it meant: "For all three starting indices return the translation that yields the most amino acids. If there is more than one sequence, return them joined by a -." 

I assumed that it meant if two starting indices yield sequences of the same length you'd need to return them all joined by dashes. I would suggest wording it more like "if the longest translation consists of multiple sequences"

âœ… Approved the contribution.
Comment: it is fine

I think this one is fine as it is, but feedback is still appreciated.

I guess the statement could be simplified, and most of the comments below have been in that direction, but maybe now it's fine?

Maybe remove the example?
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

Maybe a bit confusing, because step 0 is "choose one of the three starting indices" then you say "For all three return the translation that yields the most amino acids". So there is not really a choice, we have to do the translation for the 3 starting indices.

It doesn't prevent me to solve it, but I had to read the statement more than once to understand.

Excepted that, it seems ok.
This got close to no feedback, so even though I think it's ready I'll send it to another round of WIP in case someone wants to chime in.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!
whatever , i need to comment a contribution for a quest so i'd like to say that when i first saw the "codongame" i taught i was a mistake but right now i think this is just amazing xd
... more precison plz
I'm confused by the instruction to return the longest translation, when your "hidden messages" include several words of different lengths.

Goal
* Please delete "." in "these steps.:".

* Please define what a "stop codon" is. Is it any codon which is marked as {{Stop}} in the stub comments?

* Please define what an "open codon" is. Is it any codon which is not a stop codon?

* The answers to the above two questions may have been implied by note 1, but it is not clear. Also note 1 uses the term "start codon" instead of "open codon". As the definitions are critical to the understanding of the rules, I would suggest that note 1 should be deleted, and the definitions should be made clear before describing the translation process.

* Or should all the mentions of "open codon" be changed to "start codon" instead? The latter term seems to be more appropriate as a name to indicate it is opposite of "stop codon".

* Step 2: Please change "an stop codon" to "a stop codon".

Cover picture
* Suggest to upload a cover picture for the puzzle.

Thanks.

This is the 3rd version (!).

It is probably bordering CoC material, but I think it's fine for an easy puzzle? Feedback appreciated.

The title is ridiculous I know.

Not at all. The title is fine. In comparison to other titles, this one is sensible and connected by "Codon" to the puzzle itself. Some other ones I see have weird names like "Another brick in the wall" (P.S This is the name of a song by the band Pink Floyd), which have no clear connection to the puzzle.

- Done
- Done - Changed & moved NOTE 1 up in the statement.
- Renamed every occurence of "open codon" to "start codon"
- Done
- Will do the cover picture if I finally decide to go with a puzzle instead of a clash.

Also changed the lower bound of length(rna) to 5, to be clearer about edge cases.

I know you usually don't solve the thingies, but if you could speedrun this one, would you mind telling us how much it took you (factoring whatever time you already spent in the comprehension department)? I'm a bit unsure about the difficulty.

Ah, I'm sorry.

Each line can be considered as a separate test. You have 3 positions to explore per line, and for each position you will get a translation with a certain number of amino acids (read characters, not including the "-"). The puzzle asks for you to return the longest (in amino acids) translation for each line.

This allows for different length solutions to different lines.

Also, the puzzle guarantees that for each line, a solution exists and is unique.

I hope this makes it clearer. Do you think I should rephrase the statement?
Thanks for your feedback. How would you have phrased it?

I don't think removing the example is a good idea. The example helps me a lot in understanding what is required.

The only thing I can see to simplify the statement is to move the following sentence to Constraints section:

For each [[rna]] string a (non empty) solution exists and is guaranteed to be unique.

1. Changed:

"
You will be given n lines, each consisting of a string rna, and a codon_table in the stub comments.

Let's name a triplet of characters in A, U, C, G a codon. Let's also name UAA, UAG and UGA the stop codons, and AUG the start codon.
"

to

"
Let's name a triplet of characters in {{A, U, C, G}} a codon. Let's also name {{UAA}}, {{UAG}} and {{UGA}} the stop codons, and {{AUG}} the start codon.

You will be given [[n]] lines, each consisting of a string [[rna]], and a [[codon_table]] in the stub comments. The [[codon_table]] contains every codon and their corresponding amino acid.
"

Also added to the input section:

"STUB: The [[codon_table]], with every codon and their corresponding amino acid."

2. Changed:

"If there is more than one sequence, return them joined by a -."

to

"If that translation consists of multiple sequences, return them joined by a -."

I would avoid the use of "longest" to prevent the ambiguity around "longest with respect to the number of amino acids" and "longest as a string after being joined with -".

----------------------

Thank you for your feedback, let me know if it's fine now.
I did that, thank you again.

Maybe :

The translation process for each of the three starting indices of rna (0, 1, 2) follows these steps:
0.  Start in the CLOSED state.
Sure. Changed it, thanks.
I would suggest to add "Each string is a separate case." to the Line 1 description in Input section. (@java_coffee_cup frequently uses a similar sentence in their puzzles.)
Like this?
Yes. ðŸ‘ðŸ»

Thank you for following up and inviting me to solve the puzzle ðŸ˜†

I think the contribution should be kept as a puzzle and the difficulty can be kept as Easy:

* It took me just slightly less than 15 minutes to write up the first "working" solution to the puzzle (though not passing all the cases, further on that below), and that excludes the time for reading and understanding the statement, which I had already done when I commented earlier.

* I initially thought I might have to optimise my Python solution to read each string in a single go instead of 3 iterations for each starting index, but it turns out such optimisation isn't necessary.

Cases
* In Validator 3, why is the output for "AUGAAAUGAAAAAUGAAAUGA" "MK-MK" instead of "MKNEM"?

* I've also got different answers from you for one input in Validator 5 and one input in Validator 8, but I'd wait for the answer to the above question first - in the hope that they may point to the same issue.

* The only difference betwen Test 3 and Test 4 is that the third input string in Test 4 doesn't appear in Test 3. Please delete Test 3, or split the input strings between the tests.

* The only difference betwen Validator 3 and Validator 4 is that the third input string in Validator 4 doesn't appear in Validator 3. Please delete Validator 3, or split the input strings between the validators.

Stub generator
* Please change "line" to "rna" for consistency.

Cover picture
* Pending.

Thanks again.

- Nice!
- The constraints should allow you to guess that 3 iterations would not result in timeout.
- [AUGAA]AUGAAAAAUGAAAUGA does not return MKNEM:
AUG-AAA-AAU-GAA-AUGA (never terminates) *
- Nice catch, changed test 4 & val 4
- Done
- Pending indeed.

* I guess I need to add somewhere that the current sequence only gets stored/saved once you reach a stop codon.

Edit: Added " and store the current sequence." at the end of (2)

Quick question: I don't quite understand the "never terminates" part of your answer? The process will terminate at step 5: "entire rna string is translated", similar to what happens in the example illustrated in Goal section.

It doesn't end in an stop codon.

The example is a bit different in that it doesn't feature this case: an index with an unterminated sequence. A better example would be:

AUGCCCAAA (and the rna stops here)
AUG-CCC-AAA (starting index = 0)
MPK (current sequence)

The solution here should be an empty string but since we guarantee the existence of a unique solution such a rna will never occur.

Since this never reaches a stop codon you never store the current sequence (as now stated by point 2).

--

In practice (as far as I understand) the ribosome starts storing the amino acids into the protein the moment it reads a start codon, but it isn't until reaching a CLOSED state that it releases the new protein (sequence of amino acids).

There is a very telling animation in the link in the notes that I repost here:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Translation_(biology)

The legend for easier searching:
A ribosome translating a protein that is secreted into the endoplasmic reticulum (tRNAs colored dark blue)

If the sequence is not terminated (=reaches a stop codon), it just remains inside the ribosome and it makes sense to ignore (=not store it / print it) as we do in the puzzle here.

Thank you for the detailed explanation!

I get it now. I just have to remove the part of my original code which stores the unstored sequence at the end of the progress to pass all the tests and validators.

Yes, it's important to mention that a sequence is stored only at step 2. It should be sufficient without emphasising that any unstored sequence is ignored?

* * * * *

While I was verifying that each case indeed had a unique solution, I had an interesting finding. Out of 118 input strings ([L0, L1, L2] below denotes the lengths of the sequences formed for starting indices 0, 1 and 2 respectively, and ignoring the fact that only 112 input strings are unique):

â€¢ majority (78): [>0, 0, 0] (#0 is the answer)

â€¢ some (14): [0, >0, 0] (#1 is the answer)

â€¢ some (12): [0, 0, >0] (#2 is the answer)

â€¢ some (12): [>0, 0, >0] (either #0 or #2 is the answer)

â€¢ just one: [>0, >0, 0] (#1 is the answer)

â€¢ just one: [>0, >0, >0] (#0 is the answer)

That doesn't look very random to me!

* * * * *

Now just two more comments in addition to the cover picture:

Goal
* In the Example, please change "an open codon" to "a start codon".

Cases
* I've generated some cases which all cover a situation not covered by your cases: the lengths of some of the "joined" sequences are the same, but their lengths of just the amino acids are different.

https://pastebin.com/dELc3x3p
(The link will expire after 2 weeks.)

Case D is very interesting because while the joined sequence where starting index = 2 is the longest, it doesn't contain the most amino acids.

Case J is kind of interesting because the equal-length joined sequences have their number of amino acids differ by 2 instead of 1.

Please consider including them in the puzzle. And if possible, generate another case similar to case D.

Thanks again.

- Added this after the description of the translation (not sure if enough?)
>> "Note that the sequences are only stored when scanning a stop codon (2). That implies that if, for a given index, the translation process terminates in an OPENED state, the current sequence is lost."

- Yeah they are not random at all. The first tests are handmade, and the generator is recycled from another version that guaranteed some conditions that are no longer relevant here and affect the starts/stops.
If you want to lose some gray matter this is the code:
https://bpa.st/HKEA

--

Ah I didn't test for that lol, nice catch.

- Done (open -> start)
- Merged Small (3) & Edges (4)
- Added new test 4 with length considerations

The way the tests in 4 are done is very simple:
You want the three translations to be (MMM, M, M-M) so you just start with AUGx3 + UGA + C (for the offset) + AUGUGA + C (for the offset) + AUGUGA AUGUGA.
And that gives you three tests if you add a C or 2xC at the start (so that the solution index also changes)

10 strings gives a good but not perfect coverage but I think it should be enough.

The first string for instance is (MMM, M-M, M-M) with triple equality.
The last 3 strings are case D (MMMM, M-M-M, M)

The validators are, like in other cases, obtained with C -> A since it doesn't affect the translation (here).

--

I guess I will add a cover picture.

I would suggest to change "(2)" to "(step 2)". 

Also in the Example please change "an start codon" to "a start codon".

Everything else looks good to me!

Thank you.

Done and done.

Also, added cover picture & reference in the notes.

Thanks!

Edit: also changed line to rna in ths stub. Forgot that one before.
